text:
BOYAN SLAT: My
name is Boyan Slat,

and I'm the founder and CEO at
the Ocean Cleanup, where we've

developed the world's
first technology to rid
the world's oceans of plastic.

Right now, millions
of tons of plastic
have entered the oceans.

And they concentrate in
these five massive areas
called ocean garbage patches.

The largest one is between
Hawaii and California,

called the Great
Pacific Garbage Patch.

In the past, people proposed to
clean it up with boats and nets

to sort of go
fishing for plastic.

But this would take many
tens of thousands of years,

it would cost many billions
of dollars to do that.

And one day, I
realized that the ocean
currents, actually they rotate.

The plastic doesn't
stay in one spot.

So I thought,
well, maybe instead

of going after the
plastic, why don't we
let the plastic come to us?

Why don't we use
the natural ocean
currents in our advantage?

Then we came up with
this passive system that

is comprised out
of these very long

floating barriers, which
then allows the ocean
to basically clean itself.

So we just stay
there, the current
brings the plastic towards us.

And that way we can
first concentrate

the plastic before we
take it out and ship
it to land for recycling.

And we then calculated that with
one such system deployed for 10

years, we can
clean up about half
the Great Pacific Garbage Patch.

It's very hard to deny
that this is a problem.

You can just literally go to
a beach or take out a boat
and see it with your own eyes.
It's so physical.

Really no one can deny that
this is something that we
need to do something about.

I never really thought of
myself as an entrepreneur.
I just enjoyed making things.

It's really just
about the feeling

that you get when you
have an idea in your mind

and then seeing
that become reality.

I think there's really no better
feeling in the world than that.

I've been sort of this
inventor all my life,

but I didn't really have
a real problem to work on.

And that changed when
I was 16 years old
and I was diving in Greece.

And I realized, I came across
more plastic bags than fish.

And I thought, well, why
can't we just keep this up?

And I think that
was the one question
that kickstarted it all.

I would describe
myself as someone

who is quite obsessive
when I have an idea,

and I just continue
thinking about it.

I think it took about a
year just playing around

with different
concepts in my mind

until I had something
that I thought could work.

And then of course, it went
out of my head and onto paper.

And then to get
started, of course I

think that was just
the hardest part,

finding the resources to be
able to actually get going.

But thankfully when
[inaudible] internet

was being shared
millions of times,

which then allowed me to
build the initial team,

as well as raise
the initial capital

through crowdfunding to actually
start and make this dream
a reality.

I'm 100% sure that
we can do this.

If I would have thought
that success wasn't

one of the possible
outcomes, I probably
wouldn't have started it.

I'm sure it's challenging, and
I'm sure we'll encounter a lot
more surprises and problems.
But that's how innovation works.

It's just a continuous list
of problems to be solved.

And eventually
you will hopefully

solve that one last problem
and then you've succeeded.
